name: Michael Glennon
skills: ['Research', 'Lesgeven', 'Management', 'Hoger onderwijs', 'Sociologie']
summary:
I work in several areas: language coaching and scientific writing support for students and professionals, teaching social theory and social scientific research methods to students in higher education, and exploring the relationship between language and society with a particular emphasis on the subject of children and linguistic diversity in European urban areas.
  
Language Coaching and Writing Support: I provide language coaching for groups and individuals seeking  improvement and greater confidence in their use of academic English. I also offer support services for professionals and students working on specific scientific writing and/or formal academic English language texts, e.g. scientific articles, dissertations, theses, lectures and presentations, reports, proposals and etcetera. Additionally, I offer translation of reports, white papers or other documents for education and research.
 
E-learning, Sociology, and Higher Education: I possess more than twelve years of experience in online instruction. This experience includes teaching sociology at a college level to a wide variety of students for universities and colleges in the American Midwest, and the development of original online courses covering a wide range of topics relevant to the social sciences. Presently my course design efforts focus on enhancing the accessibility of course content. Making sure content is accessible not only to people with different learning styles, but also to people with impairments.   

Researcher and Social Scientist: I have specialized education and experience in the use of ethnographic and discourse analytic research methods. In the past I applied these skills to a social scientific research  on the subject of community based services for people with intellectual disabilities, and to the cultural politics of autism and autistic rights. Presently I am designing a framework for a comparative analysis of experiences raising multilingual children in the Netherlands and Germany.

summary:
I am an Assistant Professor of Education, Citizenship and Democracy in a Digital World at the Amsterdam School of Communication Research (ASCoR) at the University of Amsterdam (UvA). My research interests include false information, fact-checking, media literacy as well as public trust in institutions like journalism and science.

Previously I worked as a Postdoctoral Researcher at the University of Amsterdam and the European Digital Media Observatory. In this position I contributed to systematically studying the problem of misinformation and the potential of fact-checking in the Dutch and Belgian context.

Prior to this (2020-2022), I worked as a Postdoctoral Researcher in the Department of Media and Communication at Erasmus University Rotterdam, and the coordination manager of the Horizon 2020 project 'Trustworthy, Reliable, and Engaging Social Science Communication Approaches' (TRESCA).

I hold a PhD in Sociology (2020) from the University of Amsterdam. My PhD research aimed at better understanding social capital and segregation in networks. 

I am skilled in quantitative research, social network analysis, public speaking, and project management. I've been involved in a variety of data collection projects involving field experiments, lab experiments, collecting hormonal samples, scraping network data, mining text data, and conducting semi-structured interviews.

summary:
I am a highly motivated and ambitious Research Master in European Studies at Maastricht University, passionate about history, the European Union, international relations, and political decision-making. My master's thesis will explore the role of women in the European Parliament during the European Economic Community, focusing on "The ‚Äòmissing‚Äô women of European Integration".

As part of my two-year degree, I am currently interning with Dr. Aline Sierp (Maastricht University) on a research paper about norm-building in memory studies. I am also a research intern with the Contested Histories Project by Euroclio, where I write reports on controversial monuments and street names. My experience with these internships is helping me to develop my analytical and research skills.

In addition to my studies, I am the head of the Marketing department of the European Careers Association Maastricht (ECA). As the marketing team leader, I work closely with my colleagues to implement our marketing strategy and promote ECA. I am also a German teacher at Belingual Maastricht, which allows me to share my knowledge and expertise with others.

During my Bachelor's degree in political science and social and economic history, I participated in Erasmus and spent time at Tartu University, Estonia. This experience sparked my passion for history and the European idea. I was also an active member of Model United Nations, participating as an organizer, delegate, or chair in more than 10 conferences during my Bachelor's. In my last year, I discovered a passion for Marketing, which I was able to explore through an internship with the Unicorn Factory. I was also part of the Model United Nations Society G√∂ttingen, and in 2019, I organized the annual G√∂MUN conferences as deputy secretary-general. This role required me to fundraise ‚Ç¨5000 from NATO, manage the conference logistics, and ensure academic standards were met.

In my free time, I enjoy attending MUN conferences, travelling, and reading various books, such as fantasy, romance, biographies, and LGBTQ+ literature. I am also part of the UM Pride Book Club and JEF. Spending quality time with my family and friends is also important to me.

Overall, my diverse experiences and passion for European Studies make me a valuable addition to any organization or team.

summary:
As an anthropologist, I am driven by curiosity to understand socio-cultural contexts and to make that which is invisible, visible. I am skilled at seeing nuances in cases that might otherwise appear one-sided, asking probing questions rooted in social critique, and communicating complex issues in precise language. I have experience with networking, managing research projects, conducting interviews, and being flexible and open-minded as I navigate the world. Through my studies at Utrecht University, I have dealt with sustainability as a concept in relation to environmental degradation, climate alteration, rising socioeconomic inequalities, increasing mobility and accelerated change ‚Äì as well as explored the relationship between citizenship and social sustainability.

At CIEE, we work to promote diversity and inclusion through student exchange programs. A nonprofit, non-governmental organization, CIEE is the oldest and largest nonprofit study abroad and intercultural exchange organization in the U.S. Since 1947, CIEE has helped thousands of people gain the knowledge and skills necessary to live and work in a globally interdependent and culturally diverse world by offering the most comprehensive, relevant, and valuable exchange programs available. CIEE operates 67 study centers in 45 countries that support more than 286 study abroad programs for 10,000-plus students from 340 U.S. colleges and universities annually.

name: Claes de Vreese
position 1: University Professor University of Amsterdam | Director DDC
position 2: Member Royal Dutch Academy of Arts and Sciences KNAW
skills: ['Social Sciences', 'Research', 'Lecturing', 'Political Science', 'Quantitative Research', 'Journalism', 'Politics']
summary:
Claes H. de Vreese is University Professor of Artificial Intelligence and Society (2021-), with a special focus on media and democracy at the University of Amsterdam. He holds the Chair in political communication at the Amsterdam School of Communication Research ASCoR. He (co-)directs the UvA Platform Information, Communication and the Data Society (ICDS), including the Research Priority Areas Communication, Personalised Communication, and Human(e) AI. He is the founding Director of the Center for Politics and Communication (www.polcomm.org). He is member of the ICA Executive Committee and served as President 2020-21.

He is also Scientific Director of the Digital Democracy Center at the University of Southern Denmark. 

His research interests include the role of automation, algorithms, and artificial intelligence in democratic processes. This includes microtargeting, news recommenders, social media platforms, disinformation, comparative journalism research, the effects of news, public opinion and European integration. His research has been funded by several science foundation grants, including an ERC grant, VENI and VICI grants from the Dutch Science Foundation, as well as grants from various EU research programs. He has received awards for research from the International Communication Association, the Danish Science Foundation, and the Holberg Foundation. He is recipient of the Swanson Career Achievement Award (ICA, 2018), the NeFCA Career Award (2019), and he is an elected Fellow of the Royal Dutch Academy of Sciences, the International Communication Association, and the Royal Holland Society of Sciences.

From 2004-2006 and 2010-2021 he chaired the Program Group Political Communication & Journalism in The Amsterdam School of Communication Research ASCoR. Between 2005 and 2013 he was the Director of ASCoR and NeSCoR. From 2013-2016 he served as Adjunct Dean of the Faculty of Social Sciences (FMG) at UvA. De Vreese is a former member (2012-2020) and the Chair (2017-2020) of the KNAW Social Science Council (SWR). From 2017-2020 he chaired the national SSH Council.

He has published 200+ articles in international peer-reviewed journals.

He has been visiting scholar at Harvard University, Netherlands Institute of Advances Studies, University of Zurich, and SDU. He served as Editor in Chief of Political Communication (2014-2020) and the International Journal of Public Opinion Research IJPOR, and he serves on the Editorial Board of several ISI ranked journals. He has lectured in a dozen of countries and frequently appears in (inter)national news media.

name: L√©on A. van Gulik
skills: ['Qualitative Research', 'Cultural Psychology', 'University Teaching', 'Scientific Writing', 'Psychology', 'Research', 'Social Sciences', 'Religion', 'Academic Writing', 'Science', 'Higher Education', 'Writing', 'Research Design', 'Statistics', 'Editing', 'Sociology', 'History', 'Literature', 'Mental Health', 'Analysis']
summary:
Research
As a cultural psychologist as well as a scholar of religion, my academic interests are scattered across both the social sciences and the humanities. They include religious and aesthetic experiences, mysticism, meaning-making, creativity, rituality and magical thinking, and also cultural transmission, evolutionary psychology, ecological approaches (embodied embedded cognition), identity construction, consciousness, religious self-legitimation, and human atmospheres.

I also have an interest in psychoanalysis, philosophy of science, theory and method. My research skills range from quantitative methods in general to qualitative ones‚Äîsuch as interviewing, participatory observation, and content analysis‚Äîin particular. I am currently involved in two research projects: one on religious self-legitimation (together with Leonard van ‚Äòt Hul), and one on human atmospheres.

Teaching
I have extensive experience in teaching, developing teaching material, and coordinating courses in both the social sciences and the humanities (most notably cultural psychology, psychology of religion and religious studies). I have taught both undergraduate and graduate students at university and at the first, second, and last year at college (‚Äòhogeschool‚Äô) level. I have taught regular students as well as adult learners and have done so in Dutch and English.

The teaching formats of the courses I participated in range from individual supervision (more than 120 undergraduate and graduate theses) to practicals, seminars (of 10-30 students), and lectures (up to 120 students). Apart from the development of course material, I have constructed and validated exams, edited readers, wrote syllabi and for several years coordinated two courses of some 450 students each. As part of these activities, I have supervised teaching assistants and junior lecturers and offered them didactic training, intervision sessions, and personal guidance in the form of class visitations and one-on-one coaching.

Style
Co-workers and students describe me as (see testimonials):
‚Ä¢	enthusiastic and energetic
‚Ä¢	knowledgeable
‚Ä¢	approachable and reliable
‚Ä¢	loyal and critical

name: Andrew S. Hoffman
position 2: Research Associate, iHub - Interdisciplinary Hub for Digitalization & Society
skills: ['Qualitative Research', 'Data Analysis', 'Lecturing', 'Statistics', 'Research Design', 'Editing', 'Grant Writing', 'Database Administration']
summary:
Hi! I'm Andrew and I am a Data Steward in the Faculty of Social and Behavioral Sciences at Leiden University in the Netherlands.

In this capacity, I spend much of my time liaising with researchers and support staff in Cultural Anthropology & Development Sociology (CAOS) and the Centre for Science & Technology Studies (CWTS) to address any and all Research Data Management needs ‚Äì from assisting in drafting Data Management Plans, to choosing long-term data storage/archiving, assembling Publication Packages, or any number of other facets of RDM that social science researchers encounter in their work.

Additionally, I also work closely with my team of Privacy, Security, and Data Management experts in our faculty, as well as with colleagues at Leiden's Center for Digital Scholarship, to develop resources and tooling that will assist researchers and fellow RDM professionals alike in navigating the rapidly shifting and sometimes daunting landscape of new policies, protocols, and ever more forms to fill out.
 
In my previous lives, I've been a Research Data Coordinator in academic cancer medicine (NYC, US); completed a doctoral degree in sociology with a concentration in social studies of medicine (McGill University, CA); and worked as a (sometimes-competitive) oyster shucker in the great state of Maine. I've also held a couple of postdoctoral fellowships (University of Washington, USA & Radboud University, NL), where I was studying and working alongside sociotechnical infrastructure development projects, predominantly in the field of translational science & medicine. 

It is here that I gained a keen appreciation for the promises, difficulties, and overall hard work it takes to implement concepts like Open Science and the FAIR Data Principles in everyday research practices ‚Äì both in the fields that I have studied, but also in my own work as an ethnographer of knowledge infrastructures. And it was an interest in confronting these challenges as an RDM practitioner, where I could help researchers and policymakers make sense of each others' distinct epistemologies (or whatever you call it), that led me to my current work as a Data Steward.

Beyond these pursuits, I love reading novels on my morning commute to work, watching tennis in the evenings, accumulating way more LPs than I'll ever have the time to listen carefully to, and seeking out lighthouses in distant corners of the world with the partner of my dreams and the kid for whom we share responsibility.

name: Stella Pekiaridi
skills: ['Translation', 'Books', 'New Media', 'Literature', 'Editing', 'Publications', 'Photography', 'Art', 'Social Media', 'Cultural Heritage', 'Proofreading', 'Journalism', 'Writing', 'Visual Arts', 'Blogging', 'Public Relations', 'Event Management', 'Strategic Communications', 'Museums', 'History']
summary:
Cultural Management:
Since 2009, I split my time between Greece and the Netherlands, being involved in the communication, project management and facilitation of various media and art projects, specializing in intercultural productions, digital platforms and offline events. In the course of the last 3 years, I have  been involved in the pre-production, the production and the post-production of audiovisual content for  Greek and Dutch media, such as documentaries, web-docs, radio & tv news broadcasts.

Occasionally, I work as a freelance art editor and curator of photo and visual media exhibitions, as well as an independent PR and communications consultant for theatres and individual artists from the fields of performing & visual arts.

Publishing Activities: 
During the last 15 years I work as a freelance translator, editor and proofreader of literature and texts relating to the Human Sciences. My main areas of specialization are Literature, History, Art History, Archeology, Museology and Visual Arts. Language Combination: EN-EL, IT-EL, IT-EN, NL-EL.

In addition, I work as a  professional reader, columnist, book reviewer and translator at various online and offline media of cultural and literary interest. Furthermore, I design and produce content for online & social media.

Academic Research: 
After the completion of my master's studies in Culture, Media and Communication with a specialization in Visual Culture my research interests  include Visual Culture Literacy as well as the use of Photography in Old and New Media. I am currently focused on representational tactics of photographic content in photobooks and exhibitions and the role of the visual document as cultural heritage.

Papers: "Our First Murder: Exhibiting Forensic Evidence outside the Police Archive",
2nd International Conference of Photography and Theory 2012 - Photography and Museums: Displayed and Displaying, Ayia Napa, Cyprus.

summary:
Clients who are determined to communicate with their intended audience in a clear, accurate, well-organized fashion approach me to edit their scientific articles, dissertations, consultant‚Äôs reports, websites, media releases and grant proposals written in English. As an author‚Äôs editor, I work at both the linguistic level (grammar, written style, conventions, etc.) and the content-related level (readability, flow, consistency, etc.); see also  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Author_editing.

Similarly, people approach me for help with preparing presentations to professional audiences. Based on 20 years‚Äô experience in running courses on presentation skills (and scientific writing) for professionals, I work with clients to produce ‚Äústories‚Äù and visuals that audiences identify with and remember.
 
In addition, my exposure to a wide range of settings in business, academia and science & technology enables me to provide clients with authoritative translations and, where needed, transcreations from Dutch into English.

For more details of my work  see the sections ‚ÄúExperience‚Äù and ‚ÄúProjects‚Äù below.

Specialities:
Scientific papers, book manuscripts, grant proposals, reports, media releases and websites in areas such as energy, economics, agricultural science, earth sciences, earth observation, finance & management, and mathematics.

summary:
With a background of communication science, I am interested in the emancipative features of the digital sphere, new forms of journalism and the data-driven and machine-assisted propaganda. 

I am currently working on multiple research projects at various research institutions and NGOs, including Amsterdam School of Communication Research (ASCoR), The Institute of Political Science at Leiden University and Tracking Exposed. These projects utilise traditional and computational research methods such as experiments, machine learning and deep learning to investigate topics ranging from algorithmic violence to the deliberative quality of social media platforms. 

Methodologically, I have experience in both qualitative and quantitative methods, which include (hybrid) focus groups, semi-structured interviews, automated text analysis, survey, experiments and more.

summary:
I'm curious, and I like to get down to the bottom of things. So I've combined my scientific training with my passion for communication. With my company NST Science, I help people to explain complex things as simply as possible. How? By writing and editing texts, and teaching people how to convey complex messages clearly. My clients include research institutions, R&D companies and humanitarian NGOs. 

But clear communication is just one of my passions. The other is social justice. And that is why I‚Äôm the co-founder and secretary of Our Daily Bread Ukraine, a charity that helps vulnerable people in Eastern Ukraine live dignified and fulfilling lives, also during the current war. 

Time out? I'm not one for sitting around. I'd much rather be out and about or busy in the garden. But I'll happily sit down for a good film, a Ukrainian lesson or a meal with friends.

summary:
Welcome to my LinkedIn profile!

I am interested in a type of role that fits my master‚Äôs degree in social psychology; research on human behaviour. I have to knowledge to influence people to realize the desired behavior in many different kinds of situations, for example online advertising. I gained practical knowlegde to influence people. 

My personal method for finding the best solution for a problem or new challenge (commissioned by the client) is first analyzing the current situation, secondly search for statements of the problem behavior in scientific literature, after this designing an approach to address the problem behavior, then testing if this approach is effective (by using SPSS) and ultimately reporting the results and conclusions in the form of an advice.

summary:
After completing a bachelor's in psychology, I am currently engaging in the master program Work, Health and Career at the University Maastricht. This program complements my interests in mental health from a preventative perspective and specific application of mental health promotion in the workplace. With my background in psychological research, I aspire to be able to translate research into usable interventions in the work environment. Aside from mental health, I am also highly interested in the use of psychology in the legal system. 

Next to my studies, I worked in the hospitality industry which taught me effective self-management, how to coordinate my duties at work and in my studies, and hands-on teamwork. Recently I had the honour to become the student ambassador of my study program, following my passion to help future students to find their academic path. 

In my free time, I am a very social and creative person, who enjoys creating. Over the years I taught myself how to paint, sew, knit and how to create digital art. Besides that, I value investing time into my self-development and becoming happier with myself each day.
